text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Nigeria says holding sub-regional consultations on appropriate action to be taken over last Sunday's coup in Sierra Leone.
- British negotiators blame European airline competitors for deadlock in talks to end a mutual ban by Nigeria and Britain on each other's aircraft.
- Prices of perishable food items have fallen in Lagos markets, signalling plentiful harvest is around.
- Four persons aspiring to contest governorship election in Ondo state have been arrested by the police for erecting campaign billboards without permission.
- Board of directors of the $4 billion Nigerian Liquefied Natural Gas Company has been dissolved with immediate effect.
- Central bank governor Paul Ogwuma predicts faster economic growth, saying days of Nigeria's economic nightmare were over.
- Electoral commission denies releasing list of constituences for elections, saying recent reports to that effect are speculative.
- Demand for foreign exchange at weekly auction falls further to $58.47 million from $63.7 million last week.
- The two warring factions in the National Centre Party of Nigeria say they have now resolved their differences.

- Exiled Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka, an oponent of the Nigerian military government, describes Nigeria's efforts to restore Sierra Leone's deposed president as a ploy by its military rulers to curry international support for themselves.
